intro: Calamintha pauciflora, commonly known as narrow-leaved calamint, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of southern Europe. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, narrow, and slightly hairy leaves. Its small, pale blue to violet flowers are clustered in whorls along the upper stem, blooming from June to August. Calamintha pauciflora is often found in dry, rocky soils and is valued for its medicinal and aromatic properties.
